B.I: Social Life Begins and Ends With Etiquette

B.LI: A Salon where researchers gather for good conversation
A happening environment where entertainment lies in the unpredictable
A slowly but steadily growing menagerie of flora, fauna and bot

A core group of really interesting humans, animals, insects, uncategorisables, ETs and desperados
with substantive things to say on an incredibly wide range of Subjects

P.B: Join the BBC and BOINC in their climate modelling project, as a member of The Salonista Team!

BODY.P: Situated on the second floor of Crater Labs, Inc., the Atelier is not just an exhibition space but also a popular salon where friends and patrons can gather for conversation and substantive discussion. Over time the atelier has grown even as our landlords have extended their own space, and now we have not just a salon and gallery but all manner of side rooms and workshops that reflect the varied tastes of the salonistas. The salon is central to all this however, with the gallery accessible straight through.
You can find a floor plan of the atelier at The Offsite Atelier . Also at this link is a bit of a deeper explanation of some of the animals and bots and even people you are likely to meet.
If you've never been to the atelier before, start here.

When you first come up the stairs and walk into the salon, you might be overwhelmed to hear at least fifteen or twenty researchers talking about several things at once. Don't be put off because there seem to be a lot of old friends exchanging comments on issues you haven't encountered or using words you don't understand. You'll soon get familiar with the issues, and anybody will be more than happy to explain the jargon.

There is a certain amount of role playing here, for a number of reasons. First of all, intelligent people like to play. Secondly, it is relaxing to slip off the constraints of one's daily identity and slip on a bit more height, a pair of antennae, elvish wings or a few extra academic degrees. Thirdly, it answers a human need to express social conviviality by breaking bread together -- or pizza or cheesecake. And so we have bots we can summon, and riches of furnishings and education we can call upon, to make the Atelier our haven.

Although my tastes govern the look of the salon, which runs to Art Nouveau, the kitchen and workshops are modern. The central area is anchored by a large hearth in the corner. Irving Washington donated some special firewood from the Magic Forest; quite simply, it never burns down, thus sparing us the need to burn more trees, or clean out the ashpit for that matter. Occasionally we throw coated pine cones on the fire to watch the colours. Comfortable furniture fills the room, together with throw pillows and low tables with interesting bibelots, and the general design lends itself both to small conversational groups and general discussions.
Needless to say, we owe a lot to CLI's technology for the ease and comfort of our virtual lives.

Styx the Rat should be mentioned, since he began life as a pet, but became an independent creation several years ago. Styx is about two feet tall at the shoulder, quite rangy, and has glowing red eyes.

I generally like an ordered and quiet life surrounded by friends, but with a landlord like CLI things can be very unpredictable. Afgncaap5 and Garius Lupus (as well as Ampton) often become involved in some very bleeding edge alternative technologies in their quest for knowledge and profit, and occasionally the consequences have been known to pour up the stairs and into our unsuspecting laps.

We try to live by the tenets of netiquette at our salon. If you are making a morning call to pay your respects but don't have time to dwell, please do not bookmark us: rather, leave a calling card in the ongoing conversation. A few polite words make such a difference!
BODY.PULLQUOTE: We have a zero tolerance attitude to trolling.
BODY.P: Those of you with things to sell or events and clubs to advertise -- please don't. It's one thing for you to join us in discussion, and for you to tell us about your projects and events in the course of the conversation. It is quite another thing for a total stranger to interrupt the discourse by making an announcement or just trying to be enigmatic for the alleged joy of it, then leave without a word of acknowledgement or any curiosity as to who we are. We will either shun you or make spiteful remarks about you in public places.

We are aware that there are researchers whose internet interface equipment is more difficult to use than the keyboards enjoyed by the greater majority. These equipment-challenged users are in the habit of using a greatly dehydrated form of communication called txt spk. While we regret the inconvenience to that sub-group of researchers, there is a standard of English that is adhered to at the atelier. This is because we don't just greet each other and make appointments to meet elsewhere; we carry on discussions, we describe our days and, overall, we bask in the infinite subtleties of English used well.

The atelier is a balancing act: any number of virtual identities talking to each other in the same space will not survive long as a community unless they observe mutual respect, intelligibility, and a desire for consensus. This can only be achieved with well-formed English. Before the BBC operated this website, H2G2 had a number of different subcommunities speaking different languages, German and Swedish among them. With the advent of moderation, however, it became impossible to use anything other than English. The least we can all do is make sure it is good English.

A salonista is simply a regular visitor at the atelier. There are a number of us and we have lots of discussions as well as keeping each other up-to-date with news of our lives. This leads to a rather large backlog and fast-moving threads. In spite of that, the salonistas stick with their colleagues and friends, and more join us all the time. You're welcome to join too!
BODY.SUBHEADER: APPENDIX: About The Laws of Continuity
BODY.P: There is a set of guidelines we follow in the course of our role-playing, in the Atelier and on related adventures. These principles have been refined over the years and have been found to promote harmony and stimulate creativity. Here they are:
BODY.LI: 1. Respect your fellow players' free will. Do not foist actions on other players, no matter how much you desire a certain outcome. You may throw a custard pie at Player X, but it is up to Player X to say whether they caught the pie, hurled it elsewhere, or took it full in the face.

2. Respect the plot, such as it may be. If a number of players seem to be in consensus about something that is happening, it is very rude of you to leap in and change the plot entirely. Heroes and villains are of course contending for the outcome, but as part of respecting free choice, we refrain from taking over the story or twisting it violently in midstream.

3. Respect the possibilities inherent in your character. Long experience has shown that an adventure or quest is much more satisfying all around if participants restrict themselves from instant solutions. If you should be imprisoned, you could magically burst your bonds in the very next post, but where is the fun in that for everyone else? In the long run, super powers are boring.

4. Respect the environment. You may post that you discover items, but it is an imposition to invent anything which contravenes the story so far. If a group of players are in the dining room having tea, it is rude in the extreme to invent a rhino charge going through the room. Broken cups and furniture would forever have to be accounted for.

5. Respect other people's devices. Once something has been brought into the action, whether it's a pair of pliers or a garden gnome, it becomes part of the story and its existence becomes a fact of life for all other players AND audience members. Per rule 4, this power of invention must be used carefully and with consideration.

Welcome to the Atelier. The raison d'etre is good conversation. The consequences are unpredictable. The salonistas are all first-order eccentrics, geeks and geniuses, or possibly some combination of all three. If you haven't been here before, it's worth checking out our forum page at A304354, and following the offsite link to get more backstory. We've been here a long time and have a checkered past.
The previous conversation went on for extra time as your hostess and her scribe both became confounded by real-world concerns, but here we are at last, finally free of a mountain of dirty cups and fetid ashtrays. The cleaning bot Chloe won't come near us when it gets to countdown time.

LASTPOST.TEXT: i was just listening to CBC, and the tech guy was doing a piece on how Sir Tim (godfather of the internet) is a little upset about all the misinformation on the interweb. This thing about the collider got him peeved, because he had this idealization of the internet as a place for scientific discovery and discussio. Now all these rumours about the hadron collider ending the world demonstrates how misinformation abounds on the World Wide Web.

THREAD.SUBJECT: The Backroom Chat About American Politics (3) - Special Presidential Election Edition

FIRSTPOST.TEXT:
The candidates and their vice-presidential running mates have been selected by their respective party conventions, and the campaign, which has been running de facto for at least 18 months, is now on its final, official lap.
And so we are gathered here in the bar off the exhibition area to discuss American politics in all its florid and exhibitionist glory: the election of a new president.

FIRSTPOST.TEXT:
<Marv is elbow deep in a box overfull with cables and wiring, a rack needing assembling is stacked in the corner.>
OK, we need gig ethernet for all backbone routers and firewalling, 802.11a wireless for portables, regular 100baseTX for normal stuff and we can play around with standard for research. I nicked some of this stuff from my lab, hope they don't mind. I got an AS5800 for Phil to play with and four PIX 535s for me. There are assorted routers, content delivery switches and enterprise switches also. I thikn that I have a Fornax PIX blade for the 6509 as well. I'll take care of security and basic infrastructure, but I need help setting up the racks, and I do hope that CLI have enough power for this kit.
I propose that we do some research on alternative networking ideas, but to keep that stuff off the production network for now.
I also have dozens of older machines running a variety of OSen for those who want to poke about. Not too much of the bleeding edge though.
Lil, if you have a spare printer hanging about, might we use it?

FIRSTPOST.TEXT:
Note: Have a good look at this, http://www.asterlil.com/h2g2/aplanbig.htm -- it's a key part of understanding this place you have wandered into.
You come up the stairs and find yourself standing near the kitchen, looking into the salon, where a group of people sit on red velvet sofas. There is a lot of movement, as some wander up to the butlers hatch for tea or coffee or a good . Others disappear through exits on the other side of the large room, or reappear carrying books or pieces of computer equipment, or paintbrushes, or potted plants, or samples of new recipes.
A row of fishtanks occupy the far wall, inhabited chiefly by a very large school of neon tetras, and two sloths are lolling on the hearthrug in front of the fire.
The decor is Art Nouveau, and the conversation sounds interesting, if muddled, what with five or subjects evidently being discussed all together.
Next to you, you notice one of those odd little decorative tables, on which sits a silver platter half-buried in calling cards. Even as you're taking stock, someone comes up the stairs looking distracted, glances quickly round the salon, drops another card in the platter, and heads back down the stairs.
It's perhaps a little daunting, but be patient. The hostess will notice you shortly. And if she's not in, be sure that one of the salonistas will be over to welcome you.

FIRSTPOST.TEXT:
Welcome to the Atelier! If you haven't been here ever before, you should have a look at our home base, A304354, which explains (inadequately) who we are, (misleadingly) what we do, and not a word as to why. But there are illustrations, if you follow the links.
A new salonista has joined us: welcome to seraphic digitalis, or hicdig as they also allow as they are addressed.
What a scribing adventure our Bagpuss had! The whole salon was becoming restive, nudging each other and glaring at poor old Bagpuss, who was sitting at the piano, oblivious, practising Rachmaninoff and not reading all the posts in the backlog until the last minute. I think it was the "honored" part that threw him off. At any rate, he did a splendid job of composing notes that need no intercession from me, bar the prize-giving, and we are ourselves honored to present him with the traditional yet custom-tailored Scribing Award. *Chloe steps forward to present the award, a voluminous white feather quill pen whose base resembles a grand piano carved from obsidian* We also wish him a belated Happy Birthday and apologise for not having noticed at the time.
Should there be an award for getting the 42nd post? If so, it should probably take the form of a floor tile, or part of a sheet of wallpaper, since our ltp will garner enough of the things to need to put them to work. He did it again in Conversation 91X. Uncanny.
B4 invented the concept of the Last-to-the-Forum Award, and this time he wins it, and gets to wear those hairy trouser things for showing up at post 798.
Bagpuss's notes begin with the list of salonistas in order of their appearance. I rather like this, seeing it for the third time: it's a good way of maintaining a roster of active salonistas. Now hear the rest of the notes.

FG and Teuchter celebrated birthdays (your scribe apologises if he missed anyone, but everyone missed his birthday so we'll count that as even).
Topics discussed:
We talked about our Christmases and shared bad cracker jokes. How to solve football head? MR and Sting don't wash their hair. What makes a home? And how often have we moved? Photo ID, age restrictions, chips and PINs and skimming credit card details were discussed, which led into protecting our borders against diseased livestock. Tomato growing. Student furniture and lack thereof. We talked about glasses, with Mr. D revealing a fetish for traditional librarian glasses, hair bun and sweater. Naturally we moved on to the state of our brains. Some tourists asked Lil if she likes computers. The question was passed to the Salon, resulting in a discussion of different software, and how best to cook a computer. Is to text a regular verb? Computer mouses were discussed with the five-button variety being rather unpopular. Touchpads received a mixed response. Discussion of criminal penalties, what victims and families think, drink driving. Should iPods be kept in the freezer? Diets and diet books came up, with the message "just eat properly" considered most sensible. Preservation of bodies by embalming and processed soup, burial, cremation, and where to get your ashes scattered. Being walked into by people with videocameras and held up by guided tours.
World news:
Benazir Bhutto was assassinated, prompting worries about Pakistan's future. Google celebrated LEGO's 50th birthday and Salonistas agreed that LEGO is great. California introduced not-oregano vending machines, but they were only for those with a licence to take it medicinally and probably didn't stock candy bars. Or "special" brownies. Fidel Castro resigned. Earthquake in Lincolnshire, blackout in Florida (probably unconnected).
Weather:
It snowed in northern Europe, though much of the UK then went cold, grey and damp. As usual. Amy P's part of California saw violent storms, which young Faith did not appreciate. More snow at the start of March. The west of Britain was deluged. WA saw a guy building a boat with animals milling around. Lil apparently lives halfway up a mountain, rendering her safe from all but the worst floods, but meaning she gets more snow that others on her lattitude. This included eight foot in early February. Blizzards in the mid-west of America, but a warm winter in Sweden caused hedgehogs to awaken early from hibernation. However, there were then warnings of more nasty, snowy weather in the UK and Scandinavia. Later there was yet more snow, with FG and neighbours not being allowed on the road except in emergencies. Spring sprang, but winter kept holding on. Phil had a fire drill in the rain.
Medical stuff:
Lil's right eye haemorrhaged and suddenly everyone had things floating in front of their retinas. Rev. Nick's brother had had scary, gross laser surgery on his. Lil got rather nicer-sounding laser treatment, which was declared successful. Strangely and Witty went to the dentist's. A discussion of flossing followed. Later, Strangely went back again. Turns out he's starting to teethe a wisdom tooth. Ag went dizzy and passed out in the coffee shop, but was fortunately okay. Wilma chopped off her fingertip. Titania managed only a piece of fingernail. The Salonistas compared knives and said how much they'd enjoyed watching Sweeney Todd. Strangely was urged to see his GP after almost fainting, having sight and hearing fade and coughing a lot. Hyp's absence was noted and ascribed to illness and the taxman. Marv had some rather nasty pneumonia. Ag had shoulder pain. Beatrice reported that Dai was hit by a car and went to hospital where they gave him haggis. It was Burns night, so Marv gave us a wee poem. FG did her wrist in skiing, WA's back creaked. Teuchter's painful thumb let to muchos loss of earnings. Sol announced her pregnancy. Baby names were discussed, including whether to name them after Star Trek characters.
Other stuff:
Z moved house. MR had a fancy night out. Hyp had her cheerful mother to stay and sarcasm dripped down the Salon walls.
New years eve plans were discussed, with Salonistas' plans varying from working to watching TV to going down the pub to travelling miles to meet friends to beating bosses on Eledees. And possibly lighting fires in the living room. In order to recover from Hogmanay revelry Salonistas ate massive amounts of food and drank G&Ts. I'm sure that made sense at the time. Lentilla at least was tired of food.
Rosemary went jobhunting. Mr D got a job. Lots of people quit smoking, with IrvWalsh's brother lasting a full five hours before reneging on his commitment. Marv's laptop got some lovely new batteries for free after the old ones catastrophically failed. MR showed off about her iBook's long life between charges. Lentilla started smoothing out her kitchen floor. Santra may have a North American Doppelganger. Lentilla underlaid her kitchen, painted the walls and used her new Dremel twice. Irv wanted to know if the UK had heard of a song called "Electric Slide". The general answer seems to be "no, and we were happier that way."
There was much dancing.
The virtues of beer were extolled. MR was happy to have taken delivery of some mead. Phil attended the winter ales festival, but mostly stayed off stuff with the ABV in double figures. Irv and GDZ tried to remember having tasty Utah beers in 2002 or 2003. MR's bar saw a scuffle, but she was more put out by a jerkish cop. Titania had some very black tea. Teuchter celebrated her pearl wedding anniversary, which she admitted means 30th. Three months after getting a ticket for his driving, GDZ was still trying to convince the city to take his money. Grammar reared its ugly head as Santra wanted to know whether to put a comma after "generally" at the start of a sentence. Generally, the replies said no. Titania described some yoga techniques, including one about breathing through your nostrils. Phil planted tatties and shallots. Hyp's library got a metal awning over the antique doors. Ag wrote five essays in not very long. Marv had severe doubts about meeting his own project deadline. US Salonistas got to vote in the Primaries. Strangely saw bullfinches and numerous other birds. Mr D hung out with friends in Brum.
Shrove Tuesday arrived. Lil wanted sausage pancakes. Alliterative stuff was given up for lent. Titania saw a hotel painting replaced with one that was too naughty for somebody, for the post was hidden, for a while. Titania lost her glasses, causing major problems. To avoid further embarrassment I will not say where she eventually found them. People heard very noisy "bink-bink" birds, which were identified as things unfeasibly small to be making so much noise.
MR suffered identity theft in connection with her tax rebate thingy (apologies for any inaccuracies; your scribe admits to not knowing how the US system works. Or the UK one for that matter). Fortunately the local taxpayer advocate sorted things out.
Rosemary started a new job, but wanted another one. A Japanese orchestra played Smoke On The Water on Youtube, whilst a four-year-old Swede drummed. Hyp planned to get some ink. Specifically she planned to get it inserted in her skin with a hot needle. Others considered following suit or discussed existing tattoos. Lentilla treated us to a Shakespearean hokey pokey (a bit like a hokey cokey I think). MR started getting called Monty. We're not sure if that's Python, Field Marshall, Panesar, Hall, Full or Don. Irv's character was deemed fit to practise law in Arizona.
------------------------------
Well done, what? And now it's time to start anew, with fresh coffee and samovar, newly-baked cinnamon buns and mbougatses, empty ash trays and a clean carpet. Please make yourselves at home.

THREAD.SUBJECT: The Gamers Conversing in the Computer Room

FIRSTPOST.TEXT:
*In a corner of the computer users' room, where ranks of Macs and PCs give way to a coffee-and-doughnut area, the aficionados of computer gaming have gathered to chat*
*This little corner, with its Mr. Coffee, electric kettle and snack vending machine, is obviously the place where furniture goes when it's no longer good enough for the salon or the library reading room. The chairs are upholstered but nonmatching, cat-scratched, wine-spilled. They are still, however, comfortable*
*Lil pushes her chair back from her PC as the strains of music from Myst V die away. She rubs her eyes as she stands and makes her way to the "lounge", where she plugs in the kettle, fishes out a Moxon coin and obtains a pecan roll from the vending machine*
I've just finished my first world and am in the second. These graphics are a total knockout! Has anyone else played Myst V, End of Ages?

LASTPOST.TEXT: Heh. Now that's what *I* call immersion.

FIRSTPOST.TEXT:
Welcome to the atelier, as described in A304354. You know the drill. Shoes off in the foyer, be polite, no spitting.
Mol has scribed one and a half times. We belatedly awarded her the traditional trophy in the last thread, but wish to make sure she is suitably recognised this time. Thank you, Mol, for all your efforts. *Chloe presents Mol with a refill pen for her previous pen base. This pen has a red plume and is inscribed '8DX With Thanks from a grateful salon' along its length*
A double prize to ltp this time! Not only has he won the Blue mohair Trousers With Built-in Socks, but also garnered the Golden Backlog for his longest-ever post (#1722) which pretty much covered everything we had been talking about, ever. By popular acclaim, it is decided that the best prize we could offer is this Pants Exemption. *Chloe hands ltp a plaque declaiming him exempt from having to wear the LTTF mohair prize* Congratulations to you, ltp!
The MIP Award for most informative post goes to Agapanthus at #1490, on the matter of the smelliness of goat cheese (and sheep products). *Chloe gives Ag a small looseleaf notebook with her name and 'Atelier MIP-8DX' engraved in gold on the maroon leather cover*
Most Felicitous Phrasing Award: this is for Teuchter's reaction to Mika Berzinski tearing up a news report rather than lead with Paris Hilton: " for the newsreader who denied the oxygen of publicity to the bonfire of that particular vanity." *Chloe bestows a boxed paperback thesaurus upon Teuchter, the box being embossed in gold with 'Atelier MFP-8DX'*
Recipes -- Mol posted her strawberry-rhubarb compote recipe at #1583.
Welcome to new salonista jollywinegums. You have persisted, despite your initial consternation at the size of the backlog. It was nice to see Egon again, too, after a long absence. Scorpio_witch entered the salon last week, but we haven't seen her since. Probably that pesky backlog.
DISCUSSION
As usual, the weather was a recurring theme throughout the conversation. Rain was longed for, then tolerated, then gave rise to flooding.
Hypatia reported on a biblical business card shower at the Library. Agapanthus and David were both struggling with exam-stressed students.
Continued traditional v modern medicine. Salonistas took turns on the soapbox in an orderly fashion. This progressed to a debate about the influence of pharmaceutical companies on healthcare, and comparisons of the healthcare systems in difference countries.
Titania shared a map of the Stockholm underground that had been translated into English.
We talked about our shop assistant experiences, on both sides of the counter.
Salonistas complimented our hostess on her postcards.
Following Sol's visit to a car boot sale, we talked about Justin Timberlake's contribution to the worlds of music and celebrity. This was a short conversational diversion.
After Z reported working 13 hours without anything to eat, we talked about our various nutritional needs.
Fuel prices rose in the US, prompting a Salon-wide price comparison, and some consideration of the chicken-and-eggness of public transport.
We talked about the forthcoming film of Philip Pullman's Northern Lights/The Golden Compass.
Agapanthus went to see Zodiac, a film based on real events. The conversation about this quickly mutated into a discussion of past boyfriends, including the one who wrote letters in ancient Greek. This then mutated into a discussion about dutch ovens and the spit game, probably best scribed thus:
****
We saw a picture of Lentilla's green hair and several of us were Very Jealous.
We discussed tourists, the problems they cause, the benefits they bring, and the different sorts that we have experienced. Once again, Salonistas shared the soapbox fairly. The statues in Trafalgar Square featured in this discussion.
The weather over the UK bank holiday weekend was appalling, so not much gardening or picnicking but lots of DIY and decorating was done. The later bank holiday prompted further DIY work, some of it among Salonistas' neighbours. A short discussion on unsociable DIYing hours ensued.
A brief discussion on terrorists evolved into judging people on appearances, which became the similarities between major religions, which turned into a discussion of victims and racism, that evolved into a debate about rap and then somehow moved on to symbols of oppression and the way we dress.
The daft things cats do. The daft things people do.
A medical discussion resulted from Lentilla's spinal tap and Ag's heartburn. We were, as FG noted, a frail bunch this time, with some genuine ailments surfacing and several scares on top of that. We are all concerned for lentilla's MS diagnosis. Synchronously, Michael Moore's SickO was released during this conversation.
MR had difficulty in ridding herself of a former friend; short discussion.
Lil's unwelcome caller escalated his presence, and her decision to obtain a gun sparked a discussion about shooting. It also revealed to outsiders that the States aren't always as United as people think.
PWM earned a respite and betook himself to the Green and Pleasant Land for several weeks, then reported back in time for Sandy Place Summer, gas mark 4.
Marv had two job interviews and was offered both. He now has an office. With a door.
Freddie went retrograde.
FG supplied us with Fruit Bowl Ethics Shortcake at the start of the conversation; Agapanthus donated white chocolate and raspberry cake at post 403.
Solnushka was not marking.
Z accepted a job offer in South Africa.
Rosemary sat her finals.
A late frost scuppered Hypatia's soft fruit and many of her flowers. She decided, regretfully, that her garden had become too much.
Strangely wrapped himself in tin foil and took photos.
We were pleased to see that Knickerless Teacosy had been elected president of France.
Marv ran round the hills of Utah playing Capture the Flag and Mr Dreadful climbed the highest sand dune in Europe dressed as a pirate.
Lil's microwave dinner exploded.
Salonistas were shocked by the carousel accident in Estonia, the destruction of the Cutty Sark by fire, and events in north Lebanon.
Teuchter waved bye-bye to workmen and microwaved meals. Hypatia waved bye-bye to the Smellfungus and the brickhengers, and we congratulated her on this achievement. We all waved bye-bye (hopefully temporarily) to PWM (holiday) and B4 (loss of internet).
Mr Dreadful continued swordfighting and David starred in Gerschwin.
Beatrice popped to London and discovered a 15 LED backlog on her return. But this didn't stop her passing her theory driving test.
Santragenius returned from holiday in Rome, Marv popped to Canada, Wilma popped to Torquay (we do a lot of popping). Hypatia and Mol decided to rearrange their rooms.
BIRTHDAYS: Agapanthus, MR
Marv gave up bachelorhood and found happiness.
David completed his house purchase. The Sound of Gershwin was a great success.
Little Miss Nicky organised a wedding reception.
Montana Redhead dropped a jack on her foot and broke it.
Amy was involved in a very frightening car accident. She and her family were bruised and shaken but otherwise unhurt.
Solnushka tried to remove chewing gum from trousers.
Kelli visited her in-laws in Scotland. Santragenius visited Tehran.
LibrarianPear used her new egg-poacher.
David found some old teeth in his new house.
FG has tickets for the Antiques Roadshow.
We toasted absent friends.
Santra's cat ended her life at the grand age of 18.
We brought into existence the very model of a modern Mormon Den.
d'Elaphant had a passport crisis that threatened to abort his holiday plans, a crisis which only passed when his passport arrived at the Very Last Minute, via FedEx.
Lil and FG started a Pasta Support Group. FG named it Noodles Anonymous, and Wittly Moniker woriied whether this would conflict with her Pastafarianism.
Hati left to go hitchhiking somewhere in Western Europe.
A pair of sparrow-like entities swooped into the salon through the french windows, spattered the cushions with modded postings and flew out again through the window. Wandering Albatross and Mr. Dreadful valiantly fended off the intruders by imitating Peter Cook and Dudley Moore sitting on a park bench and discussing weather interminably.
FG's car went nova in the middle of nowhere, but it was a friendly sort of nowhere with a decent mechanic. Although it takes many hours to get home, the car is eventually fixed.
A man tried, unsuccessfully, to hide in Hypatia's library. He was foiled by the internal video system.
One of Lil's cats began bringing in live animals, which culminated in her being bitten by a gopher and causing a rabies scare in her village.
The British degree system and its exams were compared to that of the American one.This led to some discussion about the value of degrees in the longer term.
GDZ became involved in the purchase of a bit of pressed carbon.
d'E finally leaves for Europe, consigning Zeppo and Gummo to the care of the salon.
Other miscellaneous topics:
Hoax calls.
Slugs! Banana slugs!!
pimiento cheese
rhubarb
vegetables and their optimum preparation
tanstaafl
fets
deceitful garlic
miniature horses and zorses
sick leave
camel spiders
Well, now that the salon is freshly swept and the ashtrays are clean, it's time to start up again where we left off. As I recall, PWM was just asking about the new movie based on the Dark Materials trilogy.
Make yourselves at home!

USER.USERNAME: d'Elaphant (and Zeppo his dog (and Gummo, Zeppo's dog))

FIRSTPOST.TEXT:
Notes for 8EXth Conversation at Lil's
Welcome to the Atelier, a place where, as George Will once put it, we like digging deeply into the surface of things. Serious discussion with smiley faces. We get intense about pizza toppings. If this is your first visit, please have a look at our main forum page, A304354. Here we lay out our raisons d'etre and offer links to offsite places that tell and show more about us, the salonistas.
Hypatia made my job as your hostess very easy, except for the outlandish word processor that she used. Extension .odt indeed! She will be able to confirm whether the rendition that Chloe has copied out onto parchment for me to read is in fact what she, Hypatia, actually said. Chloe, the award, please. *Chloe steps forward bearing a quill pen set in a base of milky onyx, the feather being all the colors of an opalescent rainbow. Inset in gold on the base is the simple legend '8EX'*
Hypatia, Madame President, Ambassador to HooToo, we thank you for your work as scribe.
*Lil unrolls the parchment scroll and begins to read Hypatia's report on Conversation 8EX*
First, welcome back j`au-aemne, whom we haven't seen for a while and Irving Washington who reappeared after a very, very long coffee break! Also, welcome to hermoine1 and Sir Peeb. Sporky and Lady C celebrated birthdays and Kelli celebrated her 6th Hootooversary.
We had some interesting conversation topics, as always, for Conversation 8EX. We naturally discussed the weather. That is a given. And what weather we had! Record rainfall in much of Britain and the US resulted in some very nasty flooding. We also had the normal summer heatwave in the South and Midwest while it turned unseasonably cold in Blighty, just to offer a contrast. Then there was the forest fire in Montana.
Our other perennial topic, food, turned into a real smrgsbord. We learned that at one time or another, salonistas have eaten dead frogs, snails, alligator, rattlesnake, iguana, turtle, guinea pig, elk, moose, antelope and kangaroo. We also discussed Scotch pies, strawberries with balsamic vinegar, shared recipes for a dirty girl scout, fair food, pizza toppings, hamburgers, pasta sauce and tomatoes we either hate them or love them.
There was also a host of other topics.
*Egon sported a quiff for a 50's theme party, which led to a discussion of hairdos from our youth
*Saturation coverage of news events
*Etymology of the word berk
*The Tour de France Prologue
*Breast feeding in public
*Christian fiction
*Atlas Shrugged which led to collective responsibility which led to Africa
*Political correctness in the book trade, Tintin in the Congo, censorship and parental responsibility
*HP7
*Prosthetics and sporting competitions, disabled athletes and performance-enhancing drugs
*Netflix vs. cable
*Ethical shopping
*Music what we're listening to now
*Family backgrounds some of us are posh and some of us aren't
*Birdwatching, kingfishers and the relative merits of various binoculars also the return of the dreaded BINK BINK bird
*Traditional values will the real England please stand up
*Real estate owning vs. renting
*Culture clashes Czech cowgirl bands, American Renfests and British country line dancers
*Traffic tickets
*Over the hill entertainers
*New York City delis
*Folding bicycles
In the What's up with Salonistas category, we unfortunately had several of our members suffering health problems. Librarian Pear had several tests to monitor her heart valve replacement. Agapanthus finally got a surgery date and had a successful procedure. Teuchter started a new treatment for RA. Sporky had strep throat. Kelli had tonsillitis. Mr. D got food poisoning from sun dried tomatoes. Lil had a throat lurgy. Lentilla had a MRI. And Tod lost a filling. Ouch.
In other salonista news:
*Sol went back to teaching and discovered she was no longer allowed to call a trainee a trainee
*Z (with Timmy) moved to Blackpool and became a landlord
*Beatrice got a new job to begin in September and a new bike.
*Ag had a visit from her brother-in-law
*Lil got to operate an ancient acequia
*Sol's choir, of which Scrumpf is also a member, gave a concert
*Rosemary picked out the pattern and fabric for her wedding dress and planted a container garden
*GDZ got a new car and is celebrating one year without cigarettes
*Marv's paintball team won a competition
*Little Miss Nicky moved to new lodgings and got a 2.1 in her degree.
*Lentilla's bathroom ceiling fell in
*Birdie disappeared for over a week, but thankfully returned.
*MR finished her summer course lectures and redecorated D's room
*Mr. D is learning to speak Gaelic
*FG won 3 ribbons at the Western Montana Fair
*tartaronne got a job as the manager of a radio station
*Amy P is finally moving out of her apartment so it can be remodeled
We had a lot of coming and going this conversation!
*Teuchter and Kelli both went to the Hampton Court Flower Show
*Teuchter and her mother also visited Sissinghurst castle, Great Dixter and Rosemoor Gardens.
*FG went to a PowWow on the Flathead Reservation and camping to Bowman Lake in Glacier National Park
*The Dreadfuls went on holiday to Scotland
*Wilma went to Lebanon
*d'E returned from Italy
*Santra went to Sweden, then to Ireland
*Phil went to the Tatton Flower Show and then to the WOMAD Festival in Wiltshire
*WA went to Portugal
*tartaronne went to visit her mother
*Marv went to Las Vegas for DEFCON 15
*Rosemary went to Cornwall
*Beatrice went to London
*Bald Bloke went camping in Dorset
*Teuchter went to Scotland
*Kelli went to Scotland
*Beatrice went to Scotland
*Egon is off to New York City
*Lil looks up from the parchment scroll* As the conversation wrapped, after Hypatia had finished these notes, we had found a little website that bestowed surreal aristocratic titles and weird fortune cookies, at http://www.masquerademaskarts.com/memes/peculiartitle.php , and, thanks to Strangely's birding habits we were onto the matter of squirrels, red, gray, tufted and ingenious.
*returns to parchment and reads on, as Chloe moves forward with a whole tray of small orange gift boxes. Evidently Hypatia shopped with great forethought during her last trip to England, and made a number of purchases in Diagon Ally. Each box is labelled "Compliments of Weasleys' Wizard Wheezes" and is tied with a simple purple ribbon*
There are a lot of awards, anniversaries and special recognitions this conversation.
*As Lil reads off the awards from Hypatia's list, Chloe holds out the tray for the winner to choose a box*
The FTTF mug was won by Titania, Post 42 was snapped up by LTP, and the furry blue trousers go to HMH.
The award for the Most Bizarre Medical Event goes to Agapanthus. Her irony chip blew up. Fortunately, it was restored during her surgery.
The Smart Kitty Award goes to Cliquot who taught herself how to tinkle in the toilet. Good kitty!
The Strange Shopper Award goes to Solnushka, who went in search of a camel for B's anniversary gift.
The Best New Insult Award goes to FG for 'you Calvinist/Congregationalist with a little Anabaptist thrown in screwball!'
FG also wins the Coolest Event award for her appearance on Antiques Roadshow.
The Farthest Trip Award goes to Little Miss Nicky who visited China.
The Best Quote goes to David B for Kafka's 'The Trial' is probably best read when drunk.
The Most Unwelcome Guest Award goes to Hypatia for the raccoon in her bedroom at 3:30 am.
The Best New Literary Term goes to 'teuchter-noir', from Teuchter, of course.
The Best Animal Sighting goes to Lil for a herd of elk.
Lil also wins the Coolest Job Award for her new position as a Park Ranger.
And the Best Calling Card Award goes to Lentilla for her inventive hypercube.
And so we find ourselves on the threshold of a new conversation. What will happen? Which salonistas will distinguish themselves in fame or notoriety? What sorts of foods still haven't been discussed?
With all the talk of royalty that went on in the last thread, I have decided to announce an Honors' List shortly. Longevity is much to be admired and Hootoo elders deserve respect. But I would like to take a moment or two here to recognise another kind of royalty, those who contribute their time and talent to this place. Accordingly, there will be investiture celebrations as soon as everyone has had a chance to get into their fancy clothes and as soon as the jeweller shows up with the new stuff.
So. Please make yourselves at home!

FIRSTPOST.TEXT:
Welcome to the Atelier! If this is your first visit, please do us the honour of reading through our forum page at A304354, then come to the foyer. I assure you, you will be welcome.
Once again, Dame Witty Moniker has stepped forward and done a superb job of scribing for the most recent conversation. She also did something quite original and listed everyone in the order of their arrival, and look what an impressive list it is! I really hadn't stopped to think about how many of us there are. Anyway, let us toast Dame Witty for her excellent scribing. *Chloe steps forward with a quill pen, a snowy white plume set in a base of malachite* Witty, of course I can't give you a poison pen, but this little vial contains essence of poison ivy. It's volatile, only good for an hour, but it will inflict itself on the first person to hand-receive what you write. You can now write a check for your contractor with a happy heart.
Z, how last to the forum can a salonista be?? You were well past post 2000 when you strolled in! Let's see you in those mohair sock pants, then. Chloe just washed and air-dried them yesterday -- how do they feel?
It was wonderful to see eatsmice popping his head in to say hello, and we look forward to his more permanent return. I wish Amy had been able to stay as well.
And now, I shall read Witty's notes. <ahem>
Hypatia was First to the Forum for the first time in ages, quite appropriate after scribing the previous conversation. She even bestowed her own set of awards on noteworthy events and posts by the Salonistas.

Personal activities of note:

Agapanthus went on holiday for a week, as did Phil. And Strangely. And Br. Todaymueller. And Bagpuss. But not together, not even the same week. Sol returned from her holiday, as did Egon. Apologies if I missed anyone coming and going.
Strangelys work day took a turn for the surreal when he accompanied a work-related acquaintance to the emergency room. Sadly, the person did not survive. (WM is now immensely curious to know what Strangely does for a living.)

Popular conversation topics:
Somber weddings vs. jolly weddings. Pretty much all receptions were fairly jolly regardless of the tone of the ceremony.
A typo of Marvs name sparks a discussion of like and dislikes concerning names and nicknames.

Alcohol consumption patterns.

A possible link between education level and liberalness was debated.
Roadside memorials, are they appropriate?

Atelier Honors List:

Quiz Time!
http://www.mapmsg.com/games/statetris/

FIRSTPOST.TEXT:
Welcome to the Atelier! Our home page is A304354; if this is your very first time here, please read about us, check our links, get to know what sort of threshold you are about to step across.
There was no scribe, so your hostess went back through the entire backlog. Not only did it take a whole day, but I kept running across comments that I really wanted to respond to either again or in more depth. We had some fascinating discussions. Toward the end of the conversation one could tell that a major holiday was approaching, as we all became pre-occupied with cooking, shopping, eating and drinking.
The weather was also a preoccupation. Winter arrived during this conversation, causing at least inconvenience and at worst a complete shutdown of contact with the outside world. Most of us just felt the cold.
Since I was trolling the whole thread it was no trouble to compile another Witty Moniker List, of all those who participated.

And so here are the notes I took as I re-read what we talked about. They are fragmentary but, I hope, comprehensive!
HEALTH SCARES
Z's gran spends a bit of time in hospital
LibrarianPear announces an impending heart operation.
Agapanthus breaks a toe, leading everyone to compare notes on their broken (or never-broken) bones.
Wilma's computer dies.
Terry Pratchett is diagnosed with a form of Alzheimer's Disease.
Hypatia's Bearded Cousin #3 has a heart attack, but recovers.
Birthdays -- Lil, David B, d'Elaphant, Titania
RECIPES
onion marmalade - http://yorkshiredeli.blogspot.com/2007/04/onion-marmalade.html
red cabbage and apples: post 1958

everyone puts on their anagram costumes for Halloween.

Books -- everyone is reading but nobody seems to be reading Charlotte Heyer
wildfires consume California.

Strangeley finds his insulation strangely doesn't work.

What DVD collections do we have?
The World Series is taking place in the background, leading to occasional Tourette-like shouts of "Go Sox!"

Marv has a very painful shoulder that turns out to be broken.
Hypatia starts to experience a religious backlash to The Golden Compass, which launches a discussion of the trilogy and religious intolerance/censorship.
[American] civil war re-enactments (are there Roundhead and Cavalier re-enactors out there?)
David B experiences some disturbing house vandalism in the form of broken windows.
fixing toilets
casting a Jasper fForde novel
Lil furnishes a link to the 70's fashion experience, while Titania provides a link to angora bondage outfits, and FG finds a boutique for knitted beard and moustache cosies.
Chinese knockoffs (link courtesy of Titania)
Irv gets Lil started about Billy the Kid and the discussion turns to outlaws and criminals and sociopathy.
photos from FG of her trip, at http://www.flickr.com/photos/36208045@N00/sets/72157602941513719/
Does the Rev. Phelps have the right to take his congregation to picket funerals? FG launched this topic, which generated plenty of discussion. It even led to an historic event, in which Marv and FG found themselves on the same side of a political issue
Strangely completes the sound insulation of his floor (734).
Lentilla is approved for a booth at the Main Street Arts Festival for 2008.
feral and domesticated (i.e., owner-friendly) cats
bread machines
NIMBY about the homeless and mentally ill
other people's children, and the issue of issue
we hear for the first time of the existence of the International Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Commas.

there is (as always) much talk of exotic beers and beers made with exotic ingredients.
Wilma endures a tax (VAT) inspection, and survives unscathed.

FIRSTPOST.TEXT:
8CXth CONVERSATION OVERVIEW
We welcomed Gnomon and little Miss Nicky back to the salon. Sunny popped in and out, and Kelli dropped in to show us Spud.
MR and Sol were marking students work for much of the thread and this prompted an early debate on the correct use of the word however.
We discovered recipes for limoncello, and PWM explained what Rat Pack Tea is.
We discussed favourite watering holes, what AOL is and whether we liked it or not, power sources (in particular tidal power and wind farms), exercise and diet, Saints, remote controlled toys, earrings and earcuffs, piercings and tattoos, the escapology tendencies of dogs, morning birdsong, paper cuts.
Wandering Albatross attempted a catering venture, but the Salonistas had no collective appetite for grilled sea birds. Mr Dreadful was forced to assume another identity temporarily, and we discovered that other researchers had had similar problems with signing in to H2. And then several Salonistas found their computers updating Windows simultaneously.
MR asked for advice about a work problem resulting from two friends and colleagues becoming an item, while Kerr avoided the railway chaplain.
We compared our Easter dinners and Easter activities (which for many Salonistas was ham followed by gardening). May Day celebrations followed later in the conversation, and Mothers Day (in the US) towards the very end.
Tartaronne recommended warm milk with mashed garlic and honey to cure a cough. Codeine and alcohol were also mentioned.
We discussed the varying price of chicken on both sides of the Atlantic. And the differences between shopping and buying. This evolved into a discussion of footwear. Lentilla accidentally bought back a shirt which shed donated to a good cause, and prompted a discussion of similar repeat-purchase incidents (books being the most popular), and long-wearing clothes.
Lil asked us all to submit lists of the software we currently use, regret purchasing, and wish we still had. So we did.
We helped Hypatia to fine-tune her trip to the UK, helped Beatrice plan a trip to Spain, and enjoyed a fruit salad of mixed feelings the Salon Fruitbowl of Wonders. UK salonistas shared their photos of the micro-meet at Kew, which led to a discussion of wisteria sinister to Hypatia, but a favourite with many others. This generated a discussion about scented flowers. Salonistas like scented flowers of every type.
Postal rates around the world provided a good debate, capped by Lil who introduced us to the new, highly mathematical, Dimensional Weighting system of the US postal service.
We discussed Zs career options and liked the idea that he might work for Medicins sans Frontieres after a year in South Africa, although there was some concern for his safety.
FG offered us an Evil quiz. Not all Salonistas were Angelic or Good.
Starting with Estonia, we discussed national and regional identities within larger countries in particular, differences in accents. And then European Salonistas experienced the joy of the Eurovision Song Contest, while US Salonistas were debating whether to see Spiderman or Hot Fuzz. This transmogrified into a debate about The Matrix.
NEWS SUMMARY
Hayafi, Hypatia and Mr Dreadful celebrated birthdays; FG returned from San Francisco and Hypatia went to the UK.
Solnushka made sandwiches for 350 cyclists.
David prepared for his starring role in Kiss Me Kate by reading Dracula, and was on national radio.
Hypatia gave us the inside stories on ordering the library copy of HP7 and completing library technology plans.
Marv applied for one job and decided not to apply for another; GDZ left one job and started another.
On the home front, Teuchter ate many microwaved meals and her iron blew up, Lil carried out her annual inventory of the linen closet, Wilmas daughter caught chickenpox, late frost caught Hypatias fruit trees and Mol determined to plant some seeds. In a spooky coincidence of simultaneous hot stuff, Agapanthus midriff had a pot-roasting brisket-related accident and Beatrices midriff an iron-related one. Solnushkas toe then had a close encounter with a jar of jam. The world of housewifery is a hazardous one.
Bagpuss tried cycling to work and acquired a puncture.
David mysteriously acquired a bruise in the shape of India, Lentilla shared the result of her MRI scan and her green hair, Agapanthus purchased a pretty frock.
Salonistas were shocked by events in Virginia.
Salonistas were also shocked to hear that Kerr had been driven away from her own home.
DEs home town flooded.
Strangely-strange bought a rather fabulous camera.
David revealed the all-time strangest ever bookmark (which led to a short discussion of the smell of books), Little Miss Nicky was accepted for next years PGCE course and Rosemary completed her dissertation.
LibrarianPear went into hospital, but the collective loobrushes of the Salonistas soon had her home again. Teuchter was diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis, and after some discussion of the part that diet can play in controlling the condition, the conversation moved towards the new LED and a discussion on traditional versus modern medicine.

FIRSTPOST.TEXT:
Welcome to the Atelier! If this is your first visit, I hope you'll have a look at our forum page at A304354. We also have material offsite that gives further backstory, illustrations, and a floor plan; the link is on the forum page. We're a big place, and you might want to get yourself geographically oriented.
The most recent conversation spanned the Christmas and New Year's holidays and was notable for the sheer number of returning or dropping-in Salonistas. During the thread we were happy to see Montana Redhead return (with something more than a Yo). Hard on her heels came Demon Drawer, Rev. Nick, Seth of Rabi, Coniraya, Peripatetic Warrior Monk (once again relegated to a Sandy Place), Ormondroyd, Affy (who sneaked in and right back out), Amy Ant (Amy, let us know you're OK!), Rosemary, Wilma (just back from Lebanon), and B4.
The competition in this conversation to be last to the forum was extremely intense. Candidates vied with each other from all over Hootoo, to slide belatedly into the last beanbag.
Finalists should be aware that the prize for coming in last to the forum is no longer a cattle prod. Several threads ago it was decided by universal acclaim (wherein disagreement was ignored) that the reward for being last to the forum should be this pair of super hairy angora trousers with feet, to be worn by the winner for the first three leds then handed back in for laundering and the next competition.
At post 1739, B4 just beat out Wilma to receive this prestigious award. Congratulations, B4! *Chloe gingerly hands over the freshly washed garment, which may be admired at
http://www.answeringretirementquestions.com/stowaway/lttf.htm *
We would also like to award The Sage Observation Prize to Witty Moniker for this profound observation: "You can't wear flannel pajamas in a bed with flannel sheets. It's impossible to roll over." *Chloe hands over a potted sage plant with a purple ribbon around the terracotta pot*
And then we bestow the Wry Riposte Award to Strangely Strange who, on hearing Santragenius tell the salon that the word of the year is 'Plutoed', quickly responded, "So much better than 'mooned'!" *Chloe gives strangely a sheaf of rye in a hand-made ceramic vase*
The Most Interesting Fact award goes to Agapanthus, who gave us the etymology of 'tabby' during our regular cat discussion (see post 503) *Chloe presents Ag with an Encyclopedia Britannica CD*.
The W.C.Fields Award for Humorous Remark goes to KerrAvon, who said, "I went to midnight mass once. It wasn't my fault. People shouldn't put churches between the pub and home." *Chloe proffers Kerr a small and probably quite useless beer stein of Warshawski crystal*
Finally, we award the Rolling Blackout prize to a server somewhere on this planet for their sterling indifference to the page-refresh problem that has been plaguing all parts of h2g2 since at least the end of November last year. As of this writing, the problem is not resolved, and bbc tech staff apparently feel the problem does not belong to them. It is bemusing to look back over the entire conversation and see how many interesting things were said but not followed up on because of this. *Chloe does not step forward with a prize, being unaware that the award announcement has been posted*
Before we go on to mention the many things that were discussed in the course of the previous conversation, several events are worth of special mention. First: GDZ and the Lady J set a date, February 16 2008. Second: The Dreadfuls bought a home and have established a Dreadful Household. Third: Yet again, LTP posted to #42.

FIRSTPOST.TEXT:
If this is your first encounter of the salonista kind, welcome to the atelier. Please take a bit of time to read over our forum page at A304354, as it will explain a lot of the peculiarity you are going to encounter.
We had no scribe for the previous conversation, and your hostess was frantically distracted and obstructed by Real Life for much of November, which featured a retrograde of Freddie Mercury. These things don't affect everybody, but those who surfed this last one generally found themselves committed to fifteen impossible things before breakfast, every day.
Which is all by way of apology for the lack of comprehensive review of the last conversation.
We have a new salonista -- welcome to simpsonromany over there in the beanbag!
Without a doubt, Best Topic Award goes to Hati this time. Her conflicts with her teenage daughter led her to wonder whether anyone else had been very rebellious or had rebellious children, and this led to some fascinating personal histories. *Chloe proffers Hati a golden brooch in the shape of a teacup* Hati sometimes expresses the belief that her life and experiences are greatly unlike those of the rest of us, and that she doesn't always feel like part of the group. I think this is a good time to say au contraire, Hati! We think you are definitely an integral member of this band of salonistas, and we look forward to your original viewpoint on the matters we discuss.
Right. Who brought up the issue of pots and pans? That was definitely a runner-up as an interesting topic.
What with US elections and assassinations in London, we have had a lot of politics in this thread, too. And of course there was a quiz or two and at least a couple of recipes, some shared worries and group hugs.
I have orated just long enough to allow our maidbots Matina and Chloe to complete their cleanup of the salon. As usual where there has been no scribe, I invite you to recollect your favorite moments from the previous thread as we settle into the new one. Salonistas have just been discussing the difference between poetry and song lyrics, after collectively foaming at the mouth over the intrusive feature-bloated monster that is MS Word.
The samovar and coffee pitcher are newly filled, the cinnamon buns are fresh, the ashtrays are clean and the fireplace is snapping with pion logs. Please make yourselves at home!

FIRSTPOST.TEXT:
Welcome to the Atelier, a place about which you can find out everything by visiting A304354. Those who frequent this place are not so easily described, but it's safe to say that they are all interesting, all diverse.
The first order of business is to thank the relative newcomer, healingmagichands, for volunteering to scribe the most recent conversation, and for providing your hostess with a thorough set of notes, for which we present her with the traditional Quill Pen Award. *Chloe presents hmh with a snow-white plumed quill set in a base of white marble on the sides of which are carved a forest bed of ferns*
Many good links were provided, as usual, but I think the one which made us all laugh the hardest was provided by Lentilla, to a group of imaginary covers for bodice rippers. For this we award Lentilla with the Golden Link for 88X. *Chloe gives Lentilla a fine gold chain with an '88X' charm*
Thanks to hmh's scribing, we have a clear winner for the Last To The Forum Award! And that winner is GreyDesk at post 1248. As advertised, we have a new prize for this distinction: Chloe, please present GD with these blue mohair pants with attached feet. GreyDesk, these are yours to wear for three LEDs, at which time you may hand them back to Chloe for washing and presentation to the next winner. May they bag in all the right places!
Despite an early display of magnanimity, ltp still managed to post at #42. Congratulations!
New salonistas: We had three -- Rev. Nick, Yingcat and dgbibulli. Welcome to you all. We are all pleased to see you keeping up with our notorious backlog.
Now follows a distillation of hmh's notes, which were so prodigious that I broke them out in categories.
QUIZZES:
Kingdomality
American Geography
TRAVELS:
At various times during the thread people travelled: Mol returns from camp, David B goes to his sister's wedding,. Marv travels to Las Vegas for a convention, Healingmagichands goes to the Carolinas, Hati goes to a minimeet in Estonia, Mr. Dreadful to an LARP extravaganza (there are photos), Phil to a music festival, KerrAvon goes to Dorset on vacation, Santragenius to scout camp, Agapanthus to visit in-laws in the country, Ben goes onvacation, FG goes to New York and Philadelphia, Solnushka goes on holiday to Moscow, Tartaronne on holiday to an island off the coast of Arhus
HEALTH COMMISERATIONS:
to Sol whose pregnancy misfired this time, to GDZ who contracted a nasty case of strep, to Kelli for whom stress became a physical entity and who is safeguarding her unborn baby zealously, to Ben for her migraine, and to Mr. Dreadful who experienced the consequences of outdoor LARPING in the cold. Congrats to Kelli on a good sonogram, and to Witty Moniker for the improvement in her back.
FOOD:
Foods discussed in passing: Pot noodles, chip butties, crisp butties, sausage sarnies, eggs in the hole, scratchings, battered sausages, deep fried twinkies, mustard, goat products including goat, chicken cordon bleu, salad, rabbit stew, slow roasted tomatoes, deep fried snickers bars, blini, how to cook beetroots, and virtual blackberry crumble with vanilla ice cream.
REALWORLD NEWS:
Foiled terrorist plot fouls travel plans for total population wordwide.
Steve Irwin dies in a freak accident with a stingray.
Hati has a disastrous embarrassing infuriating work day, threatens to become an assassin
The Singing Libarian is going to sing Gilbert and Sullivan: Pirates of Penzance There is a short excursion into hats and costume items.

Someone in the Sudan is forced to marry a goat.

Amy, now situated in Quirm, has interesting encounters with debt collectors who are trying to collect on someone else's debts.
ECOLOGY:
A water use calculator is presented, and discussed at length, with suggestions for conservation. A lot of discussion is also given over to composting, garbage disposals and recycling.
Ben gives a link to a news story about tree blights: horse chestnuts, elms, oaks dying everywhere. Gypsy moths.
ROMANCE:
GDZ begins to talk seriously to J and winds up doing some activities with her [This could maybe be explained better. -Ed ]. They go on a "Date", and then things get really great. Even the kids like her. He sends her flowers, and starts another term of school.
ODDITIES:
Strangely Strange has a strange experience with Shell security while attempting to secure artistic photos of their building. Some folks decide flying kites is more interesting, possibly safer.
WM is given a mobius scarf recipe.
We have a brief visit by a Caveman, lost due to a Ffordian Rift. Ultimately, he is hustled out by CLIBOT11.
ACADEMIA:
Ben writes a paper and a sprightly discussion of footnotery ensues. We all learn what a cargo cult is.
We discuss the merits of H2G2 versus Wikipedia. A certain bias surfaces.
We define the condominium, as contrasted to flats and apartments.
Titania writes a poem about a tremendous storm in Stockholm
We discuss the English language, how it changes, the disappearance of old verb forms, and whether this is a "good thing" or not.
How to pluralize an acronym ending in "S".
PERILS:
Kelli goes so far as to use the D-word. Things settle down again. People offer advice and insight into the (possible) inner workings of a man.
Kerr has a money crisis, runs out of food. Well, almost all food. Recipe suggestions follow. Amazing what can be done with flour, lard, sugar, yeast, olive oil, and slightly manky potatoes. Suggestions for foraging also offered. This situation precipitates a discussion on planning for disasters/Armageddon.
Ben has a ceiling disaster at a rental place.
Lil gets flooded during a cloudburst, and her fridge dies during a blackout. (This leads to discourse on what to use a refrigerator cadaver for and what people did before fridges.)
MISCELLANY:
air travel nowadays, its pros and cons.
fashionable uses for ties
childhood misadventures: apparently, Mothers have a streak of absentmindedness. The Basil Fawlty library tour!
Sixties music -- band lists
one-upsmanship
the relationship of artists to galleries
the merits of Irn Bru, root beer, and ginger beer
elderly linoleum
steam trains
baby showers
the pros and cons of zoos
asthma and swimming in public pools
REAL ESTATE:
Ben is remodelling
Wilma is buying a place
HMH sells property
Lil sells property
Mr. Dreadful makes an offer on a house
Witty's house remodelling is proceeding apace.
So is Kelli's.
PHOTOGRAPHY:
Somewhere out there is a picture of Marv in a cowboy hat. Lil offers a reward for it.
Strangely is contemplating procuring a new camera, which leads to a discussion on the merits of sundry models, and we revisit the comparison of digital vs film cameras.
Lil gets some great hummingbird shots and some wonderful links appear in the photo gallery thread.
And now the salon is ready to receive us, with fresh tea in the samovar and another pan of piping warm cinnamon buns baked by Matina. Please make yourselves at home!
